qas.question: Residential construction can generate what is not carefully planned?
Site conditions, local regulations, economies of scale and the availability of skilled tradespeople all affect what?

plausible_answers.text: local building authority regulations and codes of practice

qas.question: What must local regulations conform to?
What do custom designed homes dictate in the area?

plausible_answers.text: site conditions, local regulations, economies of scale (custom designed homes are often more expensive to build) and the availability of skilled tradespeople

qas.question: What are some conditions that make the availability of skilled tradespeople vary?
What effect do technologies and resources generate?
What needs to happen to prevent building authority regulations?

context: Residential construction practices, technologies, and resources must conform to local building authority regulations and codes of practice. Materials readily available in the area generally dictate the construction materials used (e.g. brick versus stone, versus timber). Cost of construction on a per square meter (or per square foot) basis for houses can vary dramatically based on site conditions, local regulations, economies of scale (custom designed homes are often more expensive to build) and the availability of skilled tradespeople. As residential construction (as well as all other types of construction) can generate a lot of waste, careful planning again is needed here.
